Roedd yna ganddynnau yno, yn y ffordd, roedd yn cael ei ganddynnau.

Do you think that kept Joseph and Catriona in the area at that time?
No, I don't think so. I don't think so.
Because they didn't involve themselves in any of that.
Joseph was for a while the chairman of the Ystrakyn Lais Mael Voice Choir.
Was he?
Yes, and when they had concerts, in those days you would have the first half of the concert,
then you would have a break, or the interval as they call it today.
Whereas today when you go to concert, the interval, everybody gets up, well most people get up and go out
and have a comfort stop and go and have a cup of tea or coffee or whatever.
But in those days you didn't. You sat there and the chairman came up and gave a speech
for a quarter of an hour or something like that.
And then the second half of the concert would happen, and then after that everybody would go home.
That is the only time I know of Joseph partaking in the community as such.
He was loved in the community, don't get me wrong.
But I never ever remember him being totally involved.
I know, I've learnt this laterally as well, that he was very friendly with a photographer in Ystrakyn Lais Mael
called Llew Morgan, and that he met with others in their house.
I know very little about that.
I didn't know anything about it at the time.
I knew of Llew Morgan at the time, of course, because I have photographs that he took of myself
and other people in my collection.
And then of course there was TJ Davis, Tom Buff as we call him, the other photographer.
He was involved with Catriona and Joseph as well.
He and his wife Dyna, they were friends.
Did Joseph ever paint or draw you?
No, not me, but my brother.
He did a portrait of my brother when my brother was about four years old,
and he gave that to my mother, and then of course I inherited it after my mother's time.
It's a much loved painting.
I see it every morning when I wake up and I see it every night before I go to sleep,
because I have it right in front of me as I lie in bed.
My brother died when he was only 25, so it was very sad.
Catriona painted me and painted my mother, but she'd never finished my mother's portrait.
Typical Catriona.
My father modelled for Joseph now and again, because my father was a cool miner.
Yes, can you talk more about this?
I can't really, because I wasn't there when this happened, but I know that it happened,
because my father said, Joseph asked me today if I would sit down,
so that he could sketch him in those sort of positions.
So you remember him doing the panels for the Festival of Britain?
Yes, I remember going down to see those, and I remember my father talking about how big they were
and that Joseph was so small he couldn't understand how he could paint so black,
but I suppose he had to stand on the steps or something to reach the top part of the paintings,
because they were in the Glenvivian, those panels.
Yes, I remember that, and I remember seeing them being painted,
because I used to go into the studio and see the progress.
Can you tell me a bit more about that, your experience of watching Joseph paint?
Well, I was overwhelmed really, because I'd never in my life seen anything like that before.
I suppose no one else in the village had either, you know.
So I was in awe of, first of all, the enormity of the whole thing, because they were huge!
And of course, I suppose what I didn't like was the dark colours,
because I remember one day asking him, why do you paint in such dark colours?
He said, be quiet.
He said, and he must have explained something, but he wasn't too fond of explaining
and talking about the things to me as a child, but he said, it is dark, it is dark.
The men don't wear coloured clothes, you know, and they have to go down the mine.
They can't wear nice clothes to go down the mine, so it's going to be dark.
And of course, he described the area as well.
I'm a bit sad in a way, because he described the area as being a dirty place.
The Struganice was never dirty, never dirty.
But I suppose he used the wrong word.
All the valleys were grey, all grey and full of dust.
There were no really bright colours.
In some areas, the trees didn't grow because they were polluted.
And there were cold chips everywhere.
So it was grimy looking, if we describe it that way,
but the place wasn't dirty in the sense, as we use that word, dirty,
of rubbish everywhere and things like that.
The area was clean.
So I suppose that is why his paintings were so dark.
There was nothing really bright anywhere.
There were no bright colours.
And of course, his favourite colour was ultramarine.
He loved ultramarine.
And if you look at many of his paintings, not all, but many, many,
you will see ultramarine in there.
And of course, he liked viridian as well, those were his colours,
and his gold and dark browns.
He could have painted it all black because it was black and grey,
but at least he's given it a bit of body by putting these,
what I call, deep dark browns and oranges and a little bit of glowing golden colours.
I know this might sound quite obvious, but it would be good to have your point of view.
Why do you think he painted the miners and the people of Ystegun Lais
rather than the landscape, say, so much?
He is a figurative painter.
That is what he always has been.
Although there were paintings in the house which he had made, which he had painted,
before he came to Ystegun Lais, and they are quite beautiful,
very shagal-like, lovely, light, gorgeous colours.
But I think he was searching for the real man, the real working man.
And I suppose, as you know, he first came to Brecon.
Well, there were no miners in Brecon, there were farmers, of course,
but then they were dotted here and there.
I think what he wanted was a bulk of human strength, if you like.
And he found that in Ystegun Lais.
And if you read his book, Related Twilight, he explains in there
how he first saw these miners coming across the bridge
with this setting sun in the background that made them look as if they were saints with halos.
I think that is what gripped him.
And in the book he explains as well how he just couldn't stop drawing and painting those characters.
That is what he'd been searching for.
But of course what you must remember is that he was very influenced.
He was very keen, when he left Poland, he was very keen to meet the expressionists.
And so he went to France, of course, but he went to Belgium.
And there he met Constantine Permaker.
And when you look at Permaker's work, you can see what a tremendous influence and effect it had on Joseph's work.
And therefore he began to paint and draw these huge figures of men.
And I think what he was trying to do there was to show the strength and the dignity of these men
working in such dreadful, dreadful conditions.
And I think that he wanted to praise that strength, defiance really, of conquering what was underneath the ground.
Did the men of the area, the miners, did they understand why Joseph was painting them?
Yes, and I think that they were honoured in a way.
Because he brought a majesty to their work and a vigour and a shape.
No one else had painted them before.
And I suppose it took them a while to accept this.
But when they saw, especially the one that he did for the Festival of Britain, and how it was proclaimed as a great work,
the men must have felt extremely proud to be part of this.
That this man would come here and draw us, as they would say.
What does he want to draw Gormwain for?
So he brought glory to them, I think, and recognition of their strength and their sheer determination and will to live and earn a living
and support their families in the area.
And what you must remember, lots of those men came from farming communities.
But of course there weren't enough farms for all the sons in the family to have a farm.
And then they needed work, they needed jobs.
And so when the mines were in full swing, I mean my own ancestry is from farming stock in Ngarbeth, Llanddewi Breivu area in West Wales.
But of course they had to come find work.
So I think without the Gormwainers Joseph Herman would never have been on the map.
I really don't think so.
And I think he has to thank people like Dyalek for inviting him to come to us to get nice and stay with them.
Excellent.
Up next I was thinking about a lot of the miners, so your father you said, they were very, even though they worked hard and toiled hard for hours,
also wanted to better themselves and educate themselves.
And how was this expressed in the community at the time?
Well, I think on the whole the majority of coal mining men wanted their children to have a better life than they.
All right, there were fathers who wanted their sons to go down the mines.
But a great number of them wanted their children to have a better life.
And at that time of course the great thing for a miner was to have a child who went in for teaching.
And so we were all encouraged to work hard in school, to go to the grammar school and to go to college or university and get a qualification and be a teacher or a doctor.
But in some profession that didn't mean that you had to go underground.
Now in the case of my father and his generation, in my father's case, and I'm sure there are plenty of other families who have suffered this, his father was killed in a coal mining accident.
The roof caved in on his back, broke his back and my grandfather died for six days at home.
There were no hospitals in those days and he died at the age of 34, leaving my granny with six children.
Now my grandmother had four sons.
So my father's eldest brother was already down the mine, he had gone down at 14.
When my father was 14, he went down the mine and the other two boys the same.
Somebody had to earn the money.
And my grandmother took in washing and she carried this washing on her back with a babe in arms and a child either side over the mountain to deliver the washing to wherever she was taking it.
And that she was only one case of plenty of other cases of families losing husbands through coal mining accidents.
And then of course a lot of the men eventually ended up with silicosis and pneumoconiosis, my father did.
So that was the drive I think behind the coal mining community was that their children would have a better life.
And when I think of the children of my generation in the Stregon Lys, the majority have become teachers, doctors, lawyers, scientists.
I don't know of anybody who has become a painter or an artist of that sense.
Forgive me if I'm wrong, but I don't.
How did the men that did work in the local mines view Joseph's work ethic?
Well at first they couldn't come to grips with this, they couldn't understand this.
How can a man go round spending all his day drawing on a bit of paper?
So I suppose amongst themselves they must have said, who is this? What am I doing?
So they worked it.
Come on.
Ffer mae'n mynd i gael i ar ei anifiwd e.
And then of course they would say, oh mae graig doeth e.
Could you say that in English?
Oh sorry yes.
They must have said, who is this then? Who does he think he is then?
You know drawing on a bit of paper. How is he going to earn his living doing that?
Where does he get his money from then? And then most probably he's going to say, oh he's got a rich wife.
Which is quite an unusual role reversal there.
Indeed it was just not on in those days.
Emancipation of the women hadn't arrived then.
The women were at home, they looked after the family, the children, and when the man came home he had his bath ready for him and his food was ready for him.
Quite right. Good gracious me working down in those conditions.
So I think that at first they found it very strange.
But eventually they began to accept him.
And I think after that, now this is my own personal opinion, but I think after the 1951 Festival of Britain and his work being acclaimed so highly,
I think they began to see that he was making in a way a cause for the miners.
He was making a big statement.
I'm not a political animal at all, but I'm sure something must have happened.
And then they just accepted him as a quaint little quirk on the community if you like.
And did that help because he came, because he fled Poland?
Was that what did that to be?
No, now wait a minute. Now this is a misconception with people.
Joseph did not flee Poland.
He had finished his apprenticeship as a printer, right, in Poland, and he had been to, I think he'd gone to,
he posed for a very famous painter there as well as a model.
And it was time for him to leave home.
And he, of course, wanted to come to Europe to see the work of the European expressionists especially.
And his mother said to him, you should go and go now.
Now, whether she had the preconceived idea that things are not going too well,
because at that time, don't forget, no one had invaded Poland.
So he did, he left, but luckily he left early enough.
He went to France, and then only after he left was Poland invaded.
And then there was the dreadful time.
So I get cross when people say, oh, he ran away because of that. No, no, it hadn't happened then.
So, but he never went back to Poland, ever.
And of course, as everybody knows, he lost all his family there.
Anyway, I feel quite sorry for him because he used to be bad tempered sometimes.
And I'm sure now as an adult I can understand he must have suffered tremendous depressions
at the thought of having lost all his family, and especially his lovely young sister,
whom he was very, very close to.
And the other reason why I feel so sorry for him as well is that he seems to have lost all the young people in his life.
He lost his young sister. He lost his first child with Katriona.
He lost his daughter by his second wife.
And, you know, that's a lot of losing three young people in your life.
I mean, I still can't get over the fact that my brother died when he was 25.
I still remember him every day of my life.
So, you know, when you lose a child, it must be soul destroying in a way.
So I really don't know what more to say about that.
But he must have become...
So did the community of Ystradig yn Llais bring him solace with the chapel, with people, just the everyday life of Ystradig yn Llais?
I think what he appreciated so much in Ystradig yn Llais was first he was accepted.
He was accepted as one of the community.
Everybody thought of him affectionately.
They all talked to him.
They all had the time of day for him.
He felt loved and wanted.
And he says that somewhere, that he was so touched that they accepted him as he was.
And I think that helped him enormously too.
Because, you know, living in London, as they were before they came to Ystradig yn Llais, they must have felt terribly isolated in a sense.
But to come to this loving, caring community must have been like someone putting a nice big Welsh shawl round him and cooching up to him.
So, yeah, I think that is what he also appreciated, having come to live in Ystradig yn Llais.
One question I'd like to ask.
What was the feeling that there was going to be a change at the time when Joseph was living in Ystradig yn Llais?
Like you said, were things changing in the area or in the world post-war?
The men were down the mines, but like you said, they wanted their children to go out to get careers, to do better.
Was there a sort of feeling of a new dawn?
That I don't know because I was too young to understand and appreciate things like that.
I don't know.
What you must remember, the reason why they both left Ystradig yn Llais was because they were having a divorce.
So what mattered to them was getting out of the place and starting another life.
I mean, you know, Catriona dragged her feet for many years.
She didn't want to have a divorce because she loved Joseph very much.
She didn't want to have a divorce.
She didn't even want to not live with him.
It was his choice.
And then, of course, when he met this other woman, and he said that he fell in love with her.
That was really all that concerned them.
I don't think they left the community with nothing to do with a new dawn as such.
But was there a change of foot in Ystradig yn Llais generally at the time?
Well, I don't know.
I mean, you know, when he left in 1955, I left Ystradig in 1956 to go to London.
So obviously, we were all then having opportunities to go away and have an education.
So obviously, things were changing and have changed.
I couldn't go back to Ystradig yn Llais to live now.
There is nothing there for me in that cultural sense of the years when I lived there.
When you left Ystradig yn Llais, we were just about to go off to university.
Well, yeah, I went to the Royal Academy of Music in London.
So as you left Ystradig yn Llais, what was it like as a town before you left Ystradig yn Llais?
Well, it was only a village then.
Now it's become a town, but it was only a village then.
And it was just our warm community.
And at first, when I went to London, I was heartbroken.
I was terribly homesick.
The hearth was so strong.
And so I used to come home quite often, much to my father's chancra.
But he said, if you come home a few more times, you won't be going back up to London.
So I thought, oh gosh, I don't want to stay in Ystradig yn Llais then.
And then he complained later on in life that I wasn't coming down to Ystradig yn Llais often enough.
So you never can please your parents, can you?
Yeah, no, once I left really and got my feet down on the ground and started to live as an adult,
there was no way that I wanted to come back to Ystradig yn Llais to live.
You said about Joseph and Katriona moving away as they were getting a divorce.
What was their relationship like through your eyes when you knew them in Ystradig?
Well, they were just a lovely couple, you know, a very artistic couple, different to my parents.
Totally different. Their lifestyle was different, you know.
Don't forget, we were a strong mining community.
We all lived in the same way.
We all played in the streets as children.
We all went up in the woods and played all day.
We were very safe.
And there were no cars around.
Only horses and carts, which is strange to say now.
No, they were just eccentric, strange couple, which I thought were fun and great to be in the company.
They fascinated me.
And your mother got on very well.
Oh, yeah. Well, my father got on well to them as well.
But you know, it was difficult for my father. He was a coal miner.
Earning a very hard living.
And there was this man going out and drawing.
So I think quite perhaps under his breath he said,
what's this man doing? Doesn't he go to work, I guess?
Their life was so totally different to anything we knew.
It was just free and easy life, really.
Come and go, they went away a lot.
You know, they went to the continent.
I mean, today people can go anywhere.
Anybody can go anywhere these days.
They can fly here, fly there.
There was no such thing in our day.
But they did.
Of course, Katriona drove.
Joseph didn't drive.
She drove to France.
She drove to Belgium.
You know, they went to Spain.
They went to Italy.
They went to Greece.
It was unheard of in our day of mining families going off.
We couldn't afford it.
It gave you that aspiration for something different.
Yes, a different world, totally.
You know, there were celebrities in the way in our area.
So, yes, happy times.
